column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Currently in industry , fault detection and identification of causes and consequences of failures are performed by operators .
#Text=If any of these tasks are not performed correctly , adverse effects can occur , such as : reduction of product quality , process safety and lifetime of machinery .
#Text=In this scenario , condition-based maintenance helps reduce unplanned downtime and maintenance costs .
#Text=Since the induction motor is widely used in industries , fault detection in induction motors becomes an indispensable tool in condition-based maintenance .
#Text=According to statistical evidence , most induction motor failures occur in bearings ( 40 % to 90 % of large to small machines ) .
#Text=Of all the techniques for diagnosis and detection of roller bearing failures , the most common is vibration analysis .

#Text=Recently , stator current-based bearing failure detection has been shown to have relevant results with the advantage of being non-invasive and without the need for special sensors , significantly reducing maintenance costs .
#Text=The identification and fault diagnosis must be able to provide alert signals when the fault is still incipient .

#Text=Thus , still at an early stage , a maintenance action should be taken to avoid fault evolution and catastrophic failure , avoiding also unnecessary costs from unscheduled repairs and shutdowns .
#Text=Bearing failures are classified as distributed or localized .

#Text=In the first kind , the deterioration occurs in a generalized way , producing a vibration that , in the frequency domain , does not present a spectral component at a certain frequency but an increase in a broad frequency band .
#Text=Consequently , its detection becomes more difficult .

#Text=The second kind , the localized one , is the one addressed in this work and its produced vibration is associated with certain frequencies that depend on the affected bearing element ( outter race , inner race , ball and cage ) .
#Text=It should be noted that a localized fault can spread to other bearing components as the level of degradation becomes more pronounced .

#Text=The traditional monitoring method , vibration analysis , requires the installation of accelerometers or speed sensors that require accurate positioning , making this analysis costly , complex , and invasive .
#Text=So , the investments in the motor current signature analysis ( MCSA ) in the detection of roller bearing failures are justified .
#Text=This technique has become an attractive alternative because it is more accessible , simple and it does not even require the physical access to the motor itself .

#Text=However , the MCSA technique presents a great difficulty in an accurate diagnosis of localized roller bearing faults due to issues such as : the low energy of the fault related spectral components and the close presence of high energy spectral components related to the power supply or to other mechanical sources .
#Text=When the localized fault is in the early stage , the energy associated to the generated impacts is not strong enough to be detected directly in the acquired vibration signal .
#Text=Therefore , according to Salomon , the energy is even lower in the stator current , because the effects of this impact are obtained indirectly as a variation of torque .
#Text=The motor RMS current can be understood as an image of motor torque : more motor torque implies more RMS current ; less motor torque implies less RMS current .

#Text=So , periodic variations in the motor torque due to specific faults will cause periodic variations in RMS current and , consequently , amplitude modulation of the instantaneous current in specific frequencies .
#Text=Another challenge presented by localized bearing faults for both , vibration analysis and MCSA , is the variation of the element fault frequencies .
#Text=Roller bearing manufacturers provide the nominal fault frequencies for each of the elements in a roller bearing :
#Text=BPFO — Ball Pass Frequency in the Outer Race ;
#Text=BPFI — Ball Pass Frequency in the Inner Race ;
#Text=BSF — Ball Spin Frequency ;
#Text=FTF — Frame Train Frequency .

#Text=Those frequencies depend on the bearing geometrical characteristics , and can present an error from external factors such as : geometric variations imposed by the failure itself , incorrect bearing installation , cage locking , improper lubrication and ball slip , for instance .
#Text=Thus , care must be taken to avoid the analysis of spectral components not related to the defect .

#Text=In MCSA , this is a more critical concern , since it is not uncommon to have high energy supply frequency harmonics near the bearing fault frequencies , which can demand a very high-resolution spectrum to distinguish spectral components of diverse nature .

#Text=In order to correctly identify , in the current spectrum , the correct localized fault frequencies of roller bearings , this paper proposes the use of the envelope analysis of vibration signal as a first step .
#Text=The envelope analysis is successfully used for decades in the detection of incipient roller bearing faults .

#Text=In this technique , the vibration signal is bandpass filtered in a frequency range corresponding to the mechanical resonance of the system , which tends to amplify the impacts produced by a localized fault in any element of the roller bearing .
#Text=The filtered signal is then amplitude demodulated using the Hilbert transform , which results in the amplitude envelope of the mechanical resonance region .
#Text=The envelope spectrum is then obtained by the Fourier transform .
#Text=This spectrum presents the localized fault frequencies with great sensitivity .
